city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Best bread I ever made!! And I make a lot. I used my bread machine to make dough (added liquid ingredients, then flour, salt yeast). I also divided the recipe in half, and made two small loaves. So: added 1.5 cups warm water to bread machine pan, then 1/3 cup honey, 2 tablespoons melted butter, 2.5 cups bread flour, 2 cups whole wheat flour, 1.5 tsp salt, 2 1/4 tsp yeast. Then selected "dough cycle". Then took dough out 2 hrs later, separated into two equal portions and baked at 350 for around 30 minutes. Superb bread.

Awesome recipe!!  I made this last week with all whole wheat bread flour & it ended up being as dense as a brick. I normally am not a fan of whole wheat bread, but this bread is the exception. I halved the recipe and followed one reviewer's advice and kept the 1/3 cup honey. The bread was not too sweet, had a nice crispy crust and a soft interior. The bread rose to perfection and was the easiest bread to make. I will make this my definitive wheat bread recipe and know I will make this recipe at least once a week. Thank you Nita!

userID:
4942913
Display Name:
stephwest
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I would just write a review geared toward other newbies like me. I made this bread yesterday and I had never made bread before, ever. This was very easy and turned out amazing (mostly). A few points:  In the first of my 3 loaves, I was not very careful getting out the air during/after "punching" the bread down. I noticed that this loaf ended up being very dense and not as fluffy and even consistency with the other two. So after the rise where it is supposed to double, "punch" down your dough and seperate it into three loaves, then take a rolling pin (I didn't have one, just used a large glass water cup) and flatten it in to a rectangle, notice you will see all the air bubbles come out in the ends. Get the air out, then roll up the dough like a jelly roll, seam on the bottom. Pinch the sides and tuck them under and lay in your loaf pan. This recipe didn't mention how to shape the loaves so I had to google it :) But it was pretty easy.  I also took the advice of another reviewer and let the dough rise in the dryer after a cycle. It was great! Thanks!   Anyway, I loved this bread, it turned out nice for basic wheat bread. Next time I will make it sweeter, I have a major sweet tooth - maybe add some cinnamon and brown sugar. Thanks for the recipe!

This recipe is perfection!  I have made several previously disappointing attempts at baking bread in the past.  And so I was absolutely delighted (and shocked) when my loaves came out BEAUTIFULLY!  I halved the recipe and used 2 8X4 inch loaf pans.  I used 2 cups bread flour and 2 cups whole wheat flour.  I used 1/3 cup of honey.  I look forward to using more whole wheat flour next time, as well as adding some extras (flax seeds, sunflower seeds, etc).  My kids gobbled up several slices right out of the oven -- drizzled with a bit of honey -- YUM!  This one is a definite keeper!

city:

country:
None
text:
Delicious! I made the whole thing in the food processor. I put the water, honey and yeast in the food processor, pulsed a few times, and let it proof for a few minutes. I then let it rise (in the food processor) for half an hour. I then pulsed 1 or 2 times to punch it down. I added the ingredients, and the amount of flour called for in the ingredient list which ended up being the perfect amount to make the batter sticky, but fall away from the sides a little.   I scooped it out, sprayed a bowl with olive oil pam and then sprayed the dough with it too and let it sit for an hour. As a side note I love pam olive oil because it contains only olive oil and is great for lightly greasing anything, (including food) without over doing it with oil out of the bottle.   I will definitely keep this recipe!!

text:
Outrageously good!  I'll use this recipe for my WW bread.  It knocks the top rated store bought WW bread out of the competition.  Thank you, MommyFromSeattle for many of your suggestions; I used 1/3 cup honey and 1/3 cup sugar and added 4T vital wheat gluten.  I also opted to bake 2 loaves instead of 3 and this produced nice tall sandwich sized bread.  25 minutes is perfect; this has such a soft texture.  Thanks for letting me try this excellent recipe!  EDIT 6/29/09: I would go with baking for 30 minutes as today, when I cut into the middle of the loaf, it was slightly underbaked.

text:
I registered to the site only to be able to comment on this recipe. I too have been on a quest to bake the perfect whole wheat loaf. Last week I was determined to nail it and baked 6 different loaves in as many days. This one won by a mile! I really like it. Better than the bread from our bakery (which I really like too, btw). Probably not that much cheaper, maybe flour in the US is cheaper than in Australia? But worth every cent. I did get a bit confused about how much flour I needed. I made half the quantity and also let the breadmaker do the kneading. Only when the dough cycle was finished and I saw the sloppy dough did I realise that I missed something. So I added another cup 1/2 (?) of flour and kneaded it in for about 3 minutes. Still came out perfect! The only downside to the recipe that I can think of is the need to let it sit for 30 mins. That means it takes close to 2 hours from starting it to putting it in the oven. For a time poor sole mother, that requires careful planning. I also had to leave it in the oven for longer than 30 mins. Maybe my dough was still a bit too wet? I do like my bread quite dry.

I love this recipe. I have changed only a few things. I use 5 1/2 C whole wheat flour and 3 C. bread flour. for each loaf I measure out 28 oz. per loaf and it makes a perfect loaf. I also kneed the dough with my kitchen aid dough hook. I have not bought bread since I first started making bread. I also place the yeast in the water 112 degrees with 1/3 C. honey and let it proof before adding it to the first stage of the recipe. then follow recipe as it is. makes fabulous toast. Char

country:
None
text:
Love this!  I use 5 - 6 c. whole wheat flour (I grind my own, and is lighter and better than store-bought -- sooooo worth the price of the grinder) and 2 - 3 c. bread flour.  I also add approx. 1/4 c. of ground flax seeds.  It has worked perfectly for me every time.  The secret to using more whole wheat flour, is to knead it extra long and really well to get the gluten going.  I use my Bosch and mix it on 2 for about 10 minutes.  I also store my whole wheat flour, flax seed and yeast in the freezer to keep the nutrients and let my sit on the counter for 15 min or so to warm up before using them.  I look forward to trying this with 100% whole wheat, but it is so perfect for me now, that I hestitate to ruin it.  I have been using this recipe for quite a while and it is great!  I often have to do this 2x/week, as my family gobbles it up and I end up giving away at least one loaf each batch!  Thanks, tons!!!

text:
I continue to have problems making whole wheat bread,  I have tried this recipe twice, the firs time with reg. flour so that failure seems ok. but this last time I used white bread flour and whole wheat flour and yet my results are less than aceptable.  The dough rises fine the first time and is very rewarding, but the last rise in 3 bread pans is less than perfect.  The dough only rises to the top of the pan and no more.  The bread tastes great but is way too dense and nothing like a slice of bread.  Very dense and not high at all, however the flavor is great and I would love to get it to rise properly.  Anyone have suggestions???  I cannot understand why the second rise is so dissapointing.  Could it be that this is a Recipe for only two loves, and I am not putting enough dough in each pan.  I dont know but I have never been able to get an acceptable whole wheat loaf in many years.  I gave up some time ago, but know am determined to make it work.  Please feel free to Email me with advice.  Thanks

Plus the smell of bread in the oven is scrumptious.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I halved this recipe, which made one full loaf (sandwich bread size) plus about 4 rolls to sample. It took quite a while from start to finish, about 5 hours, but I don't have much experience with whole wheat flour. I kneaded the dough in my KitchenAid on speed 2 for quite a while (15 mins. or so) until I was satisfied with the feel of the dough. Then I let it rise for about an hour and 15 minutes until it was doubled. I formed my rolls and my loaf, and let rise for another half hour before baking. It came out pretty good in the end, although pretty heavy and a bit more dense than I would've liked - but it had great depth and flavor. This is a really good breakfast bread to eat toasted with cream cheese, butter, honey, jam or anything else you can think of. Good recipe as long as you know what to expect. If I were to change anything, I'd probably use less dough per loaf and let it rise longer to produce a lighter loaf for sandwich bread.

text:
My new conquest is bread, and this is a winner! I subbed white sugar for the honey, I may try brown next time for a richer flavor. I mixed it in my KitchenAid, but did all the kneading by hand. The flavor was spot on, the texture was perfect, it rose beautifully (which is an accomplishment for me!), and it kneaded really nicely. I switched the flours, used whole wheat bread flour, and all purpose, respectively, with no adverse effects. I ended up making buns with half the dough, and a giant loaf of bread with the other. Both are wonderful! Highly recommend, especially for beginners!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
ok ...this recipe is awesome!
I made it in a dual loaf bread machine borrowed from my friend.
The bread tastes great.  I followed someone else's advice and only used the first amount of honey- we don't like overly sweet bread, and often whole wheat bread is too sweet.

My 1/3 recipe for two smaller loaves is:

1 cup warm water ----           
2 tsp yeast ( I used red star bulk which said 
               1 Tbsp =1 pkg---
1 3/4 TBSP honey---    
1 2/3 cup bread flour*---    
1 TBSP sea salt---   
1 1/6 cup whole wheat flour ---   

*We have several food allergies, so instead of using regular bread flour,I used a combo of  white whole wheat flour and potato starch.  1 TBSP potato starch per cup of flour to make bread flour, put the TBSP of potato starch on the bottom of the cup,then measure white flour to make one cup      

I made a third of a batch for each loaf pan in the dual loaf bread machine, I actually started with the yeast/warm water/honey first to let the yeast work a bit longer because I used half white whole wheat flour and half whole wheat.   That loaf turned out really well- it did over rise a bit and was touching the top of the loaf pan at first rise, but the machine punched it down and it was fine.              
   The dough looked a little dry when it first started mixing so I added 2 tsp of water to it as it was kneading per bread mak

text:
Since Christmas I have been trying different bread recipes and this is the best one so far!!!!! I did however substitute brown sugar for the honey (because I had none). I also substituted some whole wheat for the bread flour and didn't need all of the 3 1/2 cups of w.w flour (just add it in 1/2 cup increments). The first time I made it I made 3 loaves but they came out small for my liking so the next time I just made 2 loaves. This was a better size for me. My husband even complimented me on this bread. It was very soft and easy to make. This is now my favorite bread recipe

Excellent recipe! I halved the recipe and made the dough into rolls about a golf-ball in size each. I have already made them three times in the past week! I great (and lightly sweet) recipe!

text:
This bread turned out pretty good.  I added 5 heaping T. of vital wheat gluten, and I think that was a little much.  The crumb was a little *too* soft.  Maybe 3 next time.  Also, it didn't rise very high.  I took 1/3 of the dough for rolls, so maybe I took too much.  Next time I'll try 2 loavs for the whole batch.  The flavor is really good.

text:
The second time I made this I used light corn syrup instead of honey to keep the sweetness but get rid of the fermented honey smell. I also found it easier to bake all 3 loaves & then freeze 2 of the loaves after baking. When I froze the dough, it took 1/2 a day to rise before cooking.

My whole family and all our friends love this recipe! I always receive compliments on this bread. I've used the recipe as is once or twice and it turned out excellent! text:
The last whole-wheat bread I made was so horrible that I had to throw it away still warm from the oven.  I probably wouldn't have tried this one if I hadn't been out of hamburger buns.  The reviewers who called it forgiving certainly aren't lying.  I let it rise in my oven on the lowest setting but the oven got a lot hotter than I had expected and the dough had more than doubled in half an hour.  I feared the worst but it turned out great.  It sliced easily and was lovely toasted.  Had a nice, delicate flavour - not too sweet, not too hearty or yeasty.

This has become my go-to bread recipe. My family loves it and it's very simple. I buy organic and GMO free ingredients and flam able to feel great about making a bread my family loves that has no preservatives. It also freezes well. I personally use a little less of the whole wheat flour as it rarely needs more than the additional 2 cups, from my experience. Tastes great with jam or honey or just butter. People often ask me for this recipe after they have tried it. If you're the type who doesn't mind hand making bread, I would absolutely recommend this recipe, any day!

text:
I LOVE this recipe! It turned out so well the first time that I am making it again now. I had never made bread from scratch before this recipe, so if it turned out well for me, anyone can do it! I don't keep bread flour in the house, but I found a substitution that works well. Add 1.5 tsp of baking powder and 1/4 tsp salt for each cup of all purpose flour to make a bread flour. So, for this recipe that calls for 5 cups of bread flour, 7.5 tsp baking powder and 1.25 tsp salt.... The smell that will fill your house while this dough is rising and baking is HEAVENLY! And this bread is good enough that you could bring a warm loaf or two to friends or neighbors. GOOD LUCK!

Display Name:
Kati
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674161.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a very forgiving recipe and amenable to a lot of changes.  The first time I made it, I made no changes excepting I never use bread flour, adding 3T. of gluten. The crust and crumb is lovely for slicing and toasting.  Since the first time, I add all the ingredients excepting the AP flour, proofing the yeast while the butter melts and the honey pours.  Then mix and let the whole mess rest for about 30 minutes.  I then knead in the AP flour via mixer then by hand.  Oh, I also use only about 3 cups of AP flour increasing the whole wheat or substituting ground oatmeal.  I don't bother with the melted butter at the end.  This has become my standard whole wheat recipe, thank you  Nita.

userID:
14589900
Display Name:
Fran Corrow
isPro:
False
followersCount:
7
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
6
favoritesCount:
26
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1633743.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow! this is by far my family's favorite wheat bread recipe. I tried using a different recipe and they new and ask for this one immediately. I made some adjustments in order to bake in my OSTER BREADMAKER. Comes out light and fluffy. Not dense. Just perfect for sandwiches. In a bowl combine: 
2 cups warm water
1 package yeast
1/3 cup brown sugar
2 cups white flour
Mix well and pour in breadmaker pan. Wait 30 min or until big and bubbly as noted above. Then add the following ingredients:
3 tbsp butter
1/4 cup brown sugar
1.5 cup wheat
1/2 cup oatmeal 
1/3 cup sunflower seeds
Select "Rapid Bake" for 1.5 to 2 pound loaf. That's it! I have added a picture of it as well.

text:
This was my 1st attempt at bread and it was easy!  I used 2 pans as suggested by others and used my Kitchenaid mixer to knead the dough.  I was short on honey, so I used sugar also, but cut the total amount used by at least half to avoid having it too sweet.  I also didn't think all the butter was necessary, so I only added 2T instead of 3, and did not coat the finished loaf with butter and it's still not hard 3 days later.  The taste is similar to store loaf bread, but slightly heartier.

country:
None
text:
This is an incredible recipe.  I have just started baking my own bread, and wasn't always happy with the results.  with a couple of minor tweaks, this one is just about perfect.  I start with whole wheat or multigrain bread flour - 5 cups mixed in with the water, yeast and honey, with 4 to 5 tablespoons of essential gluten.  Then I use white bread flour in the second step.  The dough rises beautifully, handles like a dream and I always get 3 good sized loaves - sometimes a little extra for some freeform rolls.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been using this recipe for a year.  We bake 3 loaves about every 10 days. We use a 1/2 & 1/2 mix of whole wheat flour that we buy pre-packaged and then full whole wheat that we grind ourselves. It's hard to mess up this recipe. What I love about it is minimal kneading. It seems that less is better. We now have people wanting to buy it each week and have sold it sporadically in the past. The time it takes to rise can vary a lot depending upon the temperature, so if it's going slowly, I'll put it on top of the stove next to something I'm cooking or out in the sunshine. I love that it doesn't use milk because we get our own milk fresh from the cow each morning and in the dry season there's not enough to go around...also like the honey rather than sugar.

text:
LOVE this recipe! I have made a commitment to bake all my bread to help reduce processed foods and this one is super easy and delicious! It is very forgiving and I have used all kinds of flours. If I do use all whole wheat, I add 1 TBSP of Vital Wheat Gluten ( a powder) to the dough for each cup of wheat. This adds more protein and helps the bread rise properly. I make 2 big loaves and my kids eat it up for sandwiches, morning toast, afternoon snack, whatever! We love this bread. BONUS: the house smells great when I bake it!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3149890.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this all the time. It is my go to recipe. I do leave out the second 1/3 cup of honey because I think it is too sweet. I definitly cook it for 30 minutes otherwise it is too gummy for my tastes. I also use a bocsh mixer so I don't take it out on a board to kneed it. I just add all the flour in the mixer until it doesn't stick any more. If you are not used to making bread keep reaplying olive oil to your hands when you are making each loaf, it is sticky. I don't brush the tops with butter because I like the crust better without. I think it makes it too soft. Great bread!

Very good recipe. My youngest son has a dairy allergy, so I substituted canola oil for the butter in this recipe. I am very pleased with how they turned out and how easy they were to slice when they cooled. As they cooled on a rack, I wrapped them with plastic bags, leaving just a small opening to vent. This keeps most of the moisture in as they cool. Then I sliced two loaves for putting in the freezer, and kept one out for tomorrow.

text:
This is an excellent recipe - but you can use one yeast packet and it will work just fine. I make a lot of bread for my family, so i tried one batch with the 2 packets of yeast and it was fine - but VERY yeasty tasting. Then i made another batch with only one packet of yeast. Those loaves actually had a better rise and tasted amazing.
So - this recipe is fantastic - but if you prefer a less yeasty tasting bread, use only one packet of yeast. 
:)
Thanks for posting this!

text:
This is the best recipe method I have found for making bread without any white flour. I make all of my bread with 100% whole wheat flour and have found that letting the flour set with the water and the yeast for 15-30 minutes (15 when I use instant yeast) prevents the loaf from becoming too dry and crumbly. I have also made this recipe exactly (accept for substituting whole wheat flour for the bread flour) and it was a great one; very light and moist!

I am new to bread baking and very much enjoying not only the fruits of my labor but also the labor itself. You do not have to be an experienced baker or a chemist to make good bread.  All you have to do is follow a recipe and learn from whatever mistakes you make. I followed the recipe exactly with great results.

This bread is a good example of a bread that is simple to make and delicous to eat--a perfect loaf for a beginner like me. 

The bread is slightly sweet and a little yeasty with a good crumb. A bonus is the fact that this recipe makes not one or two but three loaves, so there is plenty to go around. I understand why it is so highly regarded.

Highly recomended!

text:
I used regular all-purpose white flour instead of bread flour (I didn't have any) and it was delicious! I borrowed my mother in law's Bosch mixer and let it knead on level 1 for about 8 minutes and ended up using about 3.5 cups whole wheat flour just as the recipe states. I let the dough rise in my oven with the light on and it took about an hour.  I used two glass 9 inch loaf pans instead of three pans (time to buy another!) and cooked them together at  350 degrees for about 28 minutes. I made sure to brush them with butter and let them cool before cutting. Oh my goodness they were so good and moist, of course they made two very large sandwich loaves.  Next time I will probably do three pans just so I can fit them in the freezer better if I want to freeze a loaf :)

userID:
5711439
Display Name:
mdooley
isPro:

followersCount:
0

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A few years ago when I decided to start baking my own bread, I tried this recipe first. It worked so well, I've never tried any others. This easy recipe makes a tasty bread that's sturdy enough for toast or sandwiches.

I do just a few things differently from the recipe: I proof the yeast in 1 cup of water before adding to the rest of the water and honey. I make sure the water is around 110 degrees. I replace one cup of the bread flour with whole wheat flour. I use about half the recommended salt. And I skip the step of brushing with oil while baking, since I like it to get a little crusty on the outside. If you don't like a crust, no worries, it gets soft again if you put it in an airtight bag. The kneading lasts about 15 minutes for me; I knead until the dough gets springy and round and difficult to fold, then I go a few more minutes. Keep adding whole wheat flour to the kneading surface so that it keeps getting worked in. I also line the bread pans with parchment paper.

This bread freezes well, and comes out of the freezer smelling like fresh-baked bread. You can also freeze the dough prior to the final rise. I just love having delicious bread that I've made myself -- it's SO much better than grocery store bread!

text:
I made this bread for 20 people, and used all whole wheat flour. I used my bread machine but still followed recipe. Mixed the first half in dough mode and let it sit for 30. Then started the kneading process again and added the rest of ingredients. dough seemed a little dry given all the whole wheat so I added warm water. After dough cycle finished, punched, rolled and put it in bread pan and let it sit in fridge overnight. Took out of fridge where it sat covered for 90 min to come to room temp on top of oven. Last 15 minutes sitting out I put it on top of stove while preheating oven. Bread came out perfectly and so easy. FINALLY I have found the perfect 100% whole wheat bread that I can make in my machine and so easy!! Homemade bread every week from now on!
Review:

text:
Sweet and earthy...really nice wheat bread! I followed the recipe, needing less wheat flour than called for since the dough was so easy to manage. Next time, I'll change the ratio to have a bit more wheat than white. I ended up with two loaves and a bunch of rolls that I cooked 2/3 done and stuck in the freezer. Next time I make this, I'll not only just do two loaves so I have a sandwhich size bread, but I'll also dip the dough in rolled oats before cooking. I tried sprinkling them after brushing the butter on and they just flaked right off. Maybe someone has another solution?

Display Name:
momof3ccc

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
You must try this recipe!  The bread is so full of flavor & light in texture (even using 100% whole wheat).  This is probably the best & easiest bread recipe I've ever tried.  And I've made a lot of bread.  

After a few times making the bread, I did make it   healthier by using all 100% whole wheat & 1 cup of old fashioned oats (in place of 1 C flour) & 3 tbsp of canola oil instead of butter. Yummy & healthy & the family loves it!  However, the recipe "amounts" & "directions are perfect!  I like a little bigger loaf, so I actually made only 2 loaves & they were perfect size for sandwiches.  Best tasting flour...Bob's Red Mills 100% Organic Stone Ground Whole Wheat (& no wheat gluten needed for this recipe...perfect rise, amazing texture, not too dense at all...beautiful looking loaves.

This recipe should take you right around 3 hours to complete.  I did all proofing/kneading/rising right in same big plastic bowl.  Very simple & easy.

Best recommendation I read to help bread rise...turn on oven light & oven for 1 minutes then turn off (leaving light on).  Works like a charm! 1 hr & your bread has easily doubled.  And to give your bread a little lighter texture, you can do a 2nd rise for 30 minutes.
 
Thanks for the great recipe & all the wonderful tips!

text:
This delicious bread was very easy to make. Usually if I make bread I make a Jewish bread that takes about six hours, but this took me less than three! I didn't let it rise as long as I was supposed to, so it didn't get as large as it should have, but it was still delicious! Also, when it said to use five cups of bread flour, I substituted it for 2 and 1/2 cups of wheat flour and 2 1/2 cups of white flour. I think it made it healthier and it still tasted great! The butter on top kept it from getting too dry and hard. It was so delicious and my family really liked it I think. The was (is) a great bread for Easter! It's wonderful because it is not very time-consuming and most of the time you just let it rise...you aren't doing anything with it. I would definitely recommend this recipe to anyone who wants a quick, easy, delicious bread! Thank you so much, allrecipes.com, for this recipe! I definitely plan on using it again in the future!!!(:

text:
My kids cannot get enough of this bread! It's wonderfully tasteful and moist. It is not a very dense bread, so that makes it a bit more challenging for sandwiches. I added 4 tbsp of gluten to the recipe, and I punched down one portion of dough one extra time and then let it rise yet again, and that loaf came out a bit more dense.  This bread is fairly sweet but you could easliy cut back on the honey and increase the white/wheat flour ratio and it would still taste great.

text:
Amazing. This recipe is wonderful, and it tastes like the kind of bread I pay 4 bucks (or more) a loaf for! I made this on Saturday, gave away two of the three loaves, and then when I had to visit a friend late Sunday afternoon, I brought her the 3/4 loaf I had, knowing I could easily whip up another batch. I subbed vegetable oil for the butter, and for the batch I made today, I used brown sugar instead of honey and Earth Balance to brush after they were done baking. 

I had two big slices as toast for breakfast Sunday, with homemade strawberry jam, and man! YUM! Soft, but firm, perfect!!! bread. 

This is an easy recipe (even easier if you have a kitchen aid mixer for kneading), and I'm excited to alter it the next time I make it, maybe a cinnamon raisin or nuts-and-seeds variation. (Since there are 3 loaves, you can do 3 different breads!) Thank you Nita for giving us your recipe, I will use it for years to come!

I can't seem to get my yeast to rise with just honey, so I mixed 1/2 honey and 1/2 sugar with the yeast and it was absolutely wonderful bread.  Not too heavy and not too light. Also tried it using olive oil instead of butter and that worked out good, too.

text:
The loaves tasted great.  If you don't have "bread flour" just use all purpose.  I only gave it 4 stars because it does take a bit of practice to know how much extra flour it will need and how long to knead it.  I didn't have enough honey, so I added molasses to make up the difference.  I don't think the yeast cared.

text:
I am trying to go "waste free" at our house, which means saying no to packaged bread and the wasteful plastic wrapper. This is the best recipe I have tried for bread, so far.  It makes terrific sandwich bread for my kids' lunches. To make it close to true whole wheat, I use only 1/2-1C of white flour. Then, I use equal parts whole wheat and "white whole wheat" for the remaining flour. Also, a bit less salt, only 2.5 teaspoons. Also, if you don't want to use butter, vegetable oil works just as well. My bread pans are big, so I only get 2 loaves, but they are perfect! This recipe is terrific!

Great bread recipe; everyone loved it! I mixed and kneaded with the dough hook in a stand mixer, and let rise in a warm oven (turned on for a minute then off) for an hour. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first loaf recipe (I've done rolls and shaped loaves, but only a few times) and I think i turned out well! Just a few comments for novices like me-- 

This does fill (generously) two 9x5 pans, rather than three.  It'll be large, though.  

If you're using salted butter, still don't be afraid to use the Tbs of salt.  I cut back on the added salt, so it wouldn't be too salty-- trust me, err on the side of too much salt rather than too little. 

Knead, knead, knead. Don't stop for about 12 minutes if you're doing it by hand- and that's if you're energetic. 

Overall, I had a great rise, and a beautiful color and flavor.  The texture could have been a bit better, because I didn't knead for long enough. Best of luck!

text:
Yum!  This is such an easy and forgiving bread.  I cut the recipe in half, as hubby will only eat wheat under pressure and know I will eat the whole loaf myself.  As advised by MommyFromSeattle, used 3 tblsp gluten. Also used 2 cups all purpose and 2 cups white wheat; added 1/2 cup 8 grain cereal mix and some wheat germ.  Cooked for a total of 40 minutes and it could have used 5 more, but did not want to overcook.  Rose to great heights.  It truely looks store bought, but tastes and smells homemade.  Thanks for sharing.

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-11-20T13:16:03.493
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
2117033
Display Name:
krista v.
isPro:
False
followersCount:
26
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
133
favoritesCount:
155
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/131.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Can't stop eating this bread! This is a very easy bread recipe. I used quick rise yeast but it still needed 20 mins for the first rise. Only have 2 pans so I cut it down to 24 servings and got two loaves that didn't rise up super high (probably too cool in my house with the a/c on). Instead of bread flour I used all whole wheat flour because I prefer the taste and am trying to use less white flour in my diet. Make sure to use a good quality honey..I used an imported Hungarian wildflower variety. I'm sure orange blossom honey would be really good too. Not too big on sweet bread so I reduced the amount. On the advice of another reviewer I mixed the whole thing in my Kitchen-Aide mixer with the dough hook. The final mix before going into the pans took about 5-10 mins. It would be fun to add oats or ground flax seed just to play with the texture. I think you could also do a rosemary parmesan cheese mix for a nice savory twist, or brown sugar, raisins and cinnamon for a sweet version. Definitely try this recipe..it was a 4 hour project for me but lots of fun because the results are delicious!

text:
This bread recipe has become our staple bread for everyday.  I add a few things at the beginning - after adding 1 cup of whole wheat flower, I add 1/2 cup of white corn meal, 1/2 cup of flax seed, 2T gluten flour, 2T flax meal, and about 1/2 cup of rolled oats.  Then I add the remaining wheat flour until the consistency is right.  Great recipe (and good for you)!

text:
Love love love this recipe.  I started the mix in my old Sunbeam stand mixer with the dough hooks.  After the big and puffy experience, I transferred to board and finished kneading in the flour.  I did add an egg in the beginning and 1/3 cup dark corn syrup because I didn't have enough honey.  It was DELICIOUS. The texture is perfect, 3 loaves very useful and the taste is great.  Will be baking this one all the time.

Prep Time is way more than the 20 minutes shown.

text:
I've made this bread several times now. It is amazing. A couple things:
1) I ran into a time issue and couldn't bake the bread when I needed to. I stuck the lives in the fridge and let them finish their rise the next day. Still came out PERFECT! 
2) because it makes so many loaves and we werent likely to be able to eat it soon enough I added vital wheat gluten. The bread was really soft am lovely (softer than usual homemade bread) and it stayed fresh and soft for a week!  It made FABULOUS French toast, sandwiches (even for little kids), an regular toast.
Today my ten year old son made the recipe with only a little oversight by me. It's a really easy recipe and well worth making.

text:
This recipe is perfect. The bread makes excellent, hearty breakfast toast and sandwiches. I followed one reviewer's advice and only made two loaves (okay, so I only have two loaf pans, which certainly contributed to that decision), and they came out great. The tops were big and rounded, so the slices were generous. My family has worked through the two loaves pretty quickly, and tomorrow I need to make another for my child's lunches for the week. This recipe is kid-tested and pronounced "good." Also, this tip bears repeating... a closed oven with the light on is a great place to let dough rise.

text:
Excellent recipe! I halved the recipe and only used 1/3c honey (I think it would have been too sweet with the second addition of honey). Also, instead of bread flour I used all-purpose and added 1 T of vital wheat gluten for each cup of AP flour. I baked 2 loaves as is and the third I made into a cinnamon raisin bread and all came out wonderfully. It's a great basic recipe that I will look forward to playing around with by adding different grain flours/seeds/dried fruits and nuts.

This may be one of the few breads that tastes better the next day.  I used four small loaf pans rather than larger ones, because that is what I had.  The bread was perfect when it reached the 180 degree mark; a helpful trick.  It is great for sandwiches, as mentioned and make excellent toast.  I used two loaves for cinnamon raisin bread, which was awesome and popular at my house.  Unfortunately, this bread makes store-purchased bread taste well, not as good.

lela105

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great, fluffy wheat bread similar to white bread in texture. This is sweeter (I would call it "honey wheat"), so if you don't want a sweeter bread, I wouldn't recommend it.  I halved the recipe and made one loaf. I used all wheat bread (wheat pastry bread), so I added gluten (4 tsp), since white flour contains gluten which helps bread rise, and yeast does not usually contain gluten on its own. I also used a bread machine for some of the work. The first "mixing" I did in the bread machine bowl by hand, after it rose for the half hour, I turned my bread maker on to "dough" to let it kneed and rise. I then took it out, put it in a greased pan, let it rise again, and baked it. Made an easy recipe even easier (and less messy).  Next time, I will try using half stone ground wheat (more texture) and maybe adding some seeds or oats for even more texture.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
For the "2nd" 1/3 C Honey, I used dark molasses.  I tried to dissolve the salt into the butter too before adding and then brushed the top of the loaves before they went in the oven with egg whites to get a bit more crust.  My entire family loved this bread - it's amazing for sandwiches and doesn't collapse when you cut into it.  For added flavor, "grease" your pans with unsalted butter.  Let the bread cool all the way and then take them out.  The bottom and sides will feel damp, but the butter preserves the loaf.  Toast up a slice and there's a "brown butter" flavor effect that's incredibly rich without adding any toppings.  Winner winner winner!!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first attempt at making homemade whole wheat bread and I was so tickled at the results!  I only had 1 packet of yeast so I made half the recipe.  As suggested by another review, I sub'd sugar for honey (not enough of that either!), and 2 c bread flour, 2 c whole wheat flour, 1 tsp salt, and 3 TBSP wheat gluten.  I was not sure when to add the wheat gluten.  I ended up adding it w/the whole wheat flour (step 2).  Baked in a glass loaf pan at 350 for 25 mins, allowed it to cool slightly in the pan and then managed to get it out and cooled completely on a cooling rack.  My husband and I were both floored by the slightly sweet, chewy bread.  This is a winner!  I cannot wait to make a full batch so we can have 2 loaves!  Thanks for this recipe!!!

I've been making bread (by hand) for years and have tried many whole wheat recipes.  This is by far the best!  Most recipes add the whole wheat flour first and finish by adding the white flour.  Adding the white flour first in this recipe gives a wonderful texture and so easy to knead.  Alot of ww recipes dry out after a very short amount of time but this is a very moist, delicious bread!

text:
My first ever homemade bread, and it turned out sooooo delicious, moist on the inside, chewy crust, slightly sweet and slightly salty.  Perfect.  Kids gobbled it up immediately.  Used my KitchenAid mixer, kneading hook, but I ended up kneading  more by hand because the recipe said so ;-)  Baked mini loaves, took them out after 20 minutes from my convection oven and some of the biggest ones were still a little raw looking: tasted cooked, but looked darker in a little spot in the very centre/bottom.  Made the dough rise in the buttered pans I would eventually bake them in, and sprinkled a little flour before tossing them back in after kneading.  Substituted all purpose enriched flour for the bread flour, but the loaves still turned out really wonderful and soft and chewy.  Thank you for the fantastic recipe.

text:
My husband and I really love the taste and texture of this super easy bread! Like other users, I use this recipe to make 2 loaves instead of 3 so that it's "sandwich-sized."  I bake it at the same temperature and time as in the recipe.  Since we only eat a loaf per week, I freeze half of the dough (wrapped in plastic wrap and then a ziploc bag) before the final rising time.  The next week I just set it in the bread pan, let it rise, and then bake it.  Yum!

None
text:
I have now made this recipe half a dozen times, and every time it gets better (probably because my technique is improving!). I haven't had to add a thing to the recipe to make it come out great. I would recommend using a wheat flour made of  finely ground winter wheat, like Bob's Red Mill, if you can get it. The texture is much more chewy than if you use a coarsely ground flour. And don't bother freezing this bread, because your family is going to eat it so fast it won't have time to stale! It does freeze well, though.
Review:

userID:
166708
Display Name:
Jan Mowbray
isPro:
False
followersCount:
48
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
428
favoritesCount:
317
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2530650.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This produced 4 medium (perfect size for us) loaves of bread.  Nice texture and good flavor.  I started off following this recipe to a tee but decided to use only one half cup of honey - I don't like a sweet loaf of bread.  I found there was too much flour for the quantity of liquid. I had a very stiff dough to work with and still had another cup of WW flour to go - which I had to leave out. In my experience, it's better to incorporate all the whole wheat flour first: it's easier to incorporate white flour at the end than WW. However, next time I'll start of with at least one half cup more liquid. I didn't put the butter on the outside of the loaves either.  We love the crisp crust of a freshly baked loaf and after storage, the crust softens anyway.

text:
This recipe made the tastiest wheat bread I've ever baked!  The texture was perfect; crispy on the outside, soft and chewy inside.  The flavor had a nice balance, not too grainy or sweet (though I did use less honey than the original recipe called for).  I used sesame oil to grease the bread pans before baking, and that added a subtle sesame flavor to the crust.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this for the first time last night and it was GREAT. I only got 2 large loaves instead of 3. I made the recipe exactly as written. After I kneaded the bread for about 15 minutes I let it rise in my oven for about an hour and it was ready to be punched down and made into loaves. I then put them in the microwave to rise the second time so it would be warm enough and I would still be able to preheat the oven. In another hr they were ready to bake. I baked them for 35 minutes with a bowl of warm water on the bottom shelf of the oven and they came out perfect. My hubby and 13 yr old son almost devoured a whole loaf and my hubby normally hates wheat bread.

Display Name:
Gigi

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a wonderful and easy recipe for whole wheat bread, and works well just as written or with many different modifications as other reviewers have mentioned.  The way I usually make it is to use only 2 cups bread flour, the rest whole wheat flour.  I add some vital wheat gluten because I have so much whole wheat flour.  I replace half of the honey with molasses.  I also add a couple tablespoons of flaxseed meal and a spoonful of flaxseeds.  After the second rise and right before baking I brush the loaves with a beaten egg and sprinkle sesame seeds, poppy seeds, coarse sea salt, flax seeds, or whatever else I feel like decorating with.  Thanks to the poster for this fantastic recipe!  My family and I love it!

text:
i've been making this recipe twice a month (2 loaves each time) for about 1.5 years now. tweaked it here and there. here are a few changes that i've made that have made the bread better (i think). i substitute the butter that goes into the dough for equal amounts of walnut oil. i still brush butter across the top when it comes out of the oven. also, i add 1/8th cup of flax seed meal to each loaf. i like the nuttiness of the oil and the meal instead of the buttery flavor.

text:
I'm a novice bread maker so I didn't realize that while it IS easy, bread making DOES take time.  If making this in a Kitchen Aid mixer, you may want to reduce by 1/3 to make 2 loaves...when the inital dough rose, it was so high it oozed into the mixing tool attachment connection.  Also, I found it helpful to cover with a WET towel...the dough didn't stick to the towel.  Just some ideas from someone new to bread making.

text:
Great recipe!  When I was a little kid I made bread with my mom occasionally, but that was very rare, and this was my first time making bread on my own.  Next time I think I'll want to let it rise for a little longer, as the loafs aren't quite as tall as I hoped.. but then again I opened the oven to look inside a few times, which certainly didn't help with that.   I only had two bread pans, so I rolled the third ball of dough out flat, cut it up into rectangles, and rolled them together with cheese and veggie sausage, then put a little garlic on the top and baked them on a cookie sheet.   I'll do this again!

text:
One of the best honey wheat breads I have tasted--and I've been baking breads for a few years now!  I used in total 4 cups of wheat flour and the original amount of bread flour. As others have mentioned that three loaves makes for smaller breads, I made two loaves out of this. They were HUGE in my loaf pans. So I might make a few rolls out of it or something  (I do like big loaves, but I was afraid of it spilling over). They baked for about 35 minutes. Such GREAT flavor, soft and delicious. I think this will be my every day bread for now!

text:
First time making homemade bread: Very good bread. I added gluten and it worked out wonderfully.  suggestions/confusions: For the second 1/3c honey, butter and salt, I mixed those well together before adding it into the premature dough mixture. It seemed like it was just watery dough... and that adding 2 more cups of whole wheat flour would be too much but it turned out fine.  I didn't think it'd turn out ok because it was lump and fell apart easily but kneading it really made it come together. I will definitely be making this again! Thank you! However, I'd add more whole wheat flour and less white flour for more whole wheat taste.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Don't forget the salt! But in case you do...  Wow- this bread is basically foolproof! I forgot the salt when I mixed the ingredients and then remembered after it was rising in the fridge. (I make the bread at night and let the 1st rise happen in the fridge. Then finish it in the morning.) So I went ahead and added the salt when I took the bread out in the morning, then kneaded it for a few minutes to incorporate the salt before putting into bread pans. It worked! Perfectly. I also divided up dough into thirds and did 2 loaves of bread and 1 big pan of cinnamon rolls. Yum! I used smaller bread pans (8x4) and the bread was still awesome. It just puffs up a bit more and puffs over the sides slightly, but was perfect! I think next time I will try what others suggested and change the proportions of wheat flour to white flour so that there's more wheat than white. I'll definitely be using this recipe for my day-to-day bread.(Btw- Don't be scared to bake bread! I'm new at it, too, and this recipe is hard to screw up! Well worth it and far better for you than the preservative-laden stuff at the store!!)

text:
Perfect!  I let this rise three times.  I did not find 2/3 of a cup of honey to be too strong.  I also use half honey, half brown sugar.  The brown sugar helps give the bread a browner color.  I really think the honey helps soften the wheat flour's strong taste.  This is a great recipe because it uses both bread flour and whole wheat.  The bread flour keeps the dough from becoming too stiff and dense.  I will make this again!

text:
Excellent recipe.  I tried it for the first time today and it was surprisingly easy! And quick too.  It created a beautiful aroma throughout the house, and my husband could not wait until the bread was cooled to have some!

I ran out of honey, so I used a bit of golden syrup, and that gave an excellent flavour. I also used my bread/cake mixer (on speed 1) throughout, for exactly 10 minutes.

My only suggestion would be that the two tablespoons of butter on top, once finished is a bit too much.  One tablespoon is perfect!

I will definitely be using this recipe again.  THANKS!

This is fabulous bread . Its the first time I made bread and I'm thrilled with it . I've made it many times since , my family can't get enough of it.

text:
When I made this bread last week, it was my first time EVER making homemade yeast bread. SUPER easy and unbelievably good! Not too sweet and not at all bland. My whole family gobbled it up. I ended up making another batch 3 days later and it was gone just as quick. I followed the recipe to a "T". The only thing I did different was that I experimented with our new mill and ground my own hard red wheat flour. I know, pretty primative, but it was fun getting back to basics... if only for a little bit because I did however use my Kitchen Aid to mix and knead all the ingredients. :0) I also added 3 TBS of Gluten. After the second rise, I scored the loaves before putting the butter on top and I baked them with a pyrex of water on the bottom shelf of the oven as suggested by others.I will be making this again tomorrow to serve my in laws when they come over for dinner. Thank you for the recipe!

text:
Great recipe!  I used all whole wheat flour (South Beach Diet) and the texture turned out great.  I  cut the recipe to 2 loaves because of the size of my mixer.  I used a yeast starter and made a few minor changes in order to use it.  For 2 loaves I put in 2 1/2 cups of starter and added 1/2 cup warm water to the first step.  It took a bit longer to raise because of the starter.  I put in 1 egg along with the salt, etc. trying to give it a good consistency.  I am very excited about this and the loaves turned out beautiful and they taste great.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this bread every weekend, such a fool-proof recipe.  I do add gluten (2 tblsp) for a higher rise, and I reduce the white flour by one cup, and increase the whole wheat by a cup.  The dough has to be sticky if you increase the whole wheat, otherwise the bread is dry and crumbly.  I also use only 1/3 cup honey as I find it too sweet and increase the water by 1/3 cup.
For variation I use other whole flours such as spelt.  I also never brush the tops with butter - not necessary.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used this recipe in my bread maker. Since the original makes 3 loves I changed the serving size to 12 or 1/3 of the recipe. This automatically converts the amounts for the ingredients, but its not cut and dry. So here's the things I adjusted and calculated to make it work. I added the water, butter and honey first then all the rest of the ingredients saving the yeast for last to go in (typically the best way for bread makers). The yeast was approximately one tablespoon after I weighed it out. I also only used 3 tablespoons of honey, because the honey I have is raw, unfiltered and very dark. I only used one tablesppon of butter and didn't to the part that required the extra butter. I used the large light setting on my bread maker and it came out perfect. My family loved it so much that they ate half the loaf within the first hour of it being done. It was light and fluffy and so delicious.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7610092.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great Recipe!

I just recently started teaching myself "breads"  so far I have mastered a cinnamon roll recipe, and now this honey wheat will be a staple I keep around as well.

Would like to see how this recipe turns out with 2 loaf pans instead of 3. OR rolled up into small balls, and baked in muffin tins, 3 balls per muffin cup to make cloverleaf rolls.

Nice soft bread that cuts well for sandwiches.  Also great toasted or simply buttered!

I bought a nice clear 6" x 6" x 12" tall container that I coat with oil, and put the dough in for the 1st rise.  I can mark the level of the dough on outside of container, and easily can see when dough has doubled in size (height) since the sides go straight up.  (Sometimes it can be hard to tell when doubling has been reached when using a curved bowl that is wider at top as dough rises out and up instead of just up.)

I would highly recommend that anyone who wants to start baking bread regularly go buy a similar tall, straight sided container.

A+ recipe.

thanks!

text:
I made this bread New Year's day. I forgot to add the salt, but it was still wonderful.

I used King Arthur flours. If you use these flours you may want to use either a little less flour or a bit more water. I used about 2.5 cups of whole wheat flour. I also used SAF instant active yeast. I didn't do the 30 minute autolase. I don't think it was necesssary.

I made this in two loaf pans. I like a taller loaf than those depicted in the video. 

The bread had excellent crumb and a delicious flavor. I wish there werre more whole wheat flour. I will probably play with the ratio of bread to wheat flour a bit.

This is a great recipe! I am a relatively new bread baker and found this recipe to be reliable, accurate, and satisfying. The only thing I do differently from the original is that I halve the recipe and instead of dividing the dough into thirds, I bake it as one large loaf for about 45 minutes. text:
I have made this recipe three times now. My family loves it, and so do the people with whom I've shared. I was low on honey the first time I made it and substituted molasses for the first 1/3 c of honey. I used mostly molasses/treacle the second time (forgot honey at the store), and all honey the third time. I think I like the half and half. The molasses adds a nice depth to the bread as well as a little color... not to mention it cuts the cost per loaf and adds iron and other nutrients.

text:
The slightest changes included blooming the yeast in 1 cup of warm water (100-105 degrees) with 2 tsp of sugar. Let sit for 3 min unstirred. Then sit until all is dissolved and let sit another 10 min before pouring into flour mixture. Also only used 2 tsp of salt rather than tablespoon because low salt diet of family member. Braided the dough into two loaves and baked as directed.

text:
What fabulous bread! I ended up using a couple of cups of multigrain bread flour as well as the whole wheat, and it turned out exactly the way I wanted! Soft, chewy, tight crumb, flavourful bread. I don't find it too sweet at all, and the honey gives it a lovely flavour. I'm glad it makes a full three loaves, as I'm already half way through a loaf for "tasting purposes." One pointer; I'd watch your mixture carefully during the first proofing. It can overproof easily,  and then it won't rise as nicely in the oven.  Other than that, it's a very easy recipe, and I'll be using it regularly! Thank you!

text:
This is my first time making this bread...or any bread for that matter, which I realized undervalues my opinion at this point, but I must share. 
First of all, my house smells absolutely amazing. You know how the really good pretzel places in the mall smell like? The ones where they make them right in front of you. It's like that, but BETTER!
With this recipe I made two 5x9 loaves, two 6 inch bread twists, four bagels and a lumpy blob my 5 year old son created. While they were cooking, I made some shells and cheese, not the good kind, but the kind you get at Aldi...which will do in a pinch. After I buttered one of the twists, I ate it warm with my huge bowl of shells and cheese. I quickly realized that I was committing a culinary offense by eating this sacred bread with the chemical cheese residing in the bowl before me. It won't happen again, trust me!
Another noteworthy item would be the flexibility of the recipe. With my complete lack of bread making experience, I had absolutely no idea how much dough to use for one bagel. Was I supposed to let it rise? Do I roll it out super thin like an ink pen with the expectation that it will grow to average bagel size in the oven? I've made Pillsbury crescent rolls before that sh** is magic!
The other option was to roll them about a tiny bit smaller than what I expected as the finished product and hope for the best. I chose the later option, but I admit, I didn't set foot out of that kitchen for fear of hearing the hiss of dripping do

None
text:
Iâve been making this recipe 1-2 times a week for a few months now and I think I have the recipe how I like it. Here are the changes Iâve made:

First,  I use my KitchenAid mixer for the main kneading step. I did this step by hand the first dozen or so times I made it. I have noticed no difference in using the mixer, beyond saved energy.  

Next, I add 1 cup of oatmeal and decrease bread flour to 4 cups during the first step.

Third, I increase the wheat flour from 3 1/2 cups to 4 cups. This might vary depending on where you live, but it seems pretty consistent where Iâm at.

Fourth, I add 1/2 cup of pumpkin seeds & 1/2 cup of sunflower seeds to the dough at the end of the  kneading in the wheat flour.

Fifth, I slice the dough along the center before baking. It tends to rise a lot and this controls how it expands.

Finally, I vary up how I finish the loaf. If Iâm looking to make it look pretty, I use an egg wash and sprinkle with seeds. If Iâm looking to enhance the flavor, I brush it with butter after baking. However, out of laziness, I often do nothing beyond letting it cool. It may not look as good as it can, but it is still presentable and tasty.

text:
Love this bread! Iâm a bread baking novice, and this is darn near foolproof. I used a heavy duty bowl lift KA mixer and kneaded it on 2 for about 5 minutes. I added sunflower & pepitas to the tops of two of the loaves before the second rise. I had mixed results. Hereâs the method I tried: Dampen a tea towel & spread seeds on the towel. Shape the loaf & sort of rock the top & sides of the loaf in the seeds. 1st loaf I did that with was less than satisfactory; most of the seeds failed to stick. Second loaf: I shaped the loaf and sprinkled water all over the top, then dumped it over into the seeds and rocked it back & forth. That worked!! Makes for a wonderful crunch on the crust.

Display Name:
Allison Perry

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6182572.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this bread about a half-dozen times and it always turns out great. I love the simplicity of this recipe! I now make just a few modifications to it:

-I just made it using 5 cups of white whole wheat flour mixed with 1/4 cup vital wheat gluten instead of the bread flour. I just wanted to make the entire loaf whole wheat. The vital wheat gluten adds the extra protein that bread flour would have, giving it a good rise. 

-I use 1/4 cup of honey instead of 1/3 cup in both instances. Still tastes plenty sweet in the end but cuts back slightly on sugar. 

When I made it with these modifications, it only took about 2-3/4 cups regular whole wheat flour added in after the second rise to get the dough to the correct 'barely tacky' consistency.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-12-27T21:53:42.883

text:
My grandmother was born in 1887 (I'm not a young man). 
 She cooked by texture, taste and smell.  Her bread was the best I've ever had until now.  This is a very simple, rock solid recipe.  I used bread flour, not all purpose flour, per the recipe.  Fairly certain that's important. Unlike the video I let the dough rise about 1/2" above the pan.  This did not diminish the old style denseness of the bread at all.  You will be glad you tried this one especially if you are new to making homemade bread.

country:
None
text:
Great recipe! - my go-to for a number of years. Three loaves makes this perfect for my big family.. leftovers or a loaf to share.  Like others, I have made slight changes. My favorite is simple.. reduce the whole wheat flour to 3 cups, and add 2 cups (more or less) of cooked steel cut oats (dough will be quite tacky.) It's the perfect way to use up leftover cereal, and we love the extra moist, textured loaf with crunchy crust. (How I cook my oats: 3c water, 1c steel cut oats.. brown slightly.. 7 minutes in electric pressure cooker, 20 minutes to release pressure.)

5

text:
Kept ingredients all the same but did as suggested by others, and used two tins instead of three. I dropped the wife at work, the kids at school, then started to bake,  yet still had the loaves out of the oven by 1200. First time making bread - Who knew it would be so easy??  I kept things simple by using my Kenwood. For the second rise after all of the kneeding was done, I poured oil in then coated the outside of the dough. This only left the mixing bowl when it was time to be cut and placed in the bread tins. And blow me down, all three of my fussy kids eating the same food when the came home from school - my eight year old even insisted on taking a few slice to share with the kids next door!!

text:
Turned out great! I cut the honey and did half/half on my flour instead of 5/3 (4 cups bread/4 cups whole wheat) so that it was a regular whole wheat bread and it was delicious. I also added all of the flour at once instead of in segments. Mine took about 45 minutes to bake though, maybe because I added more whole wheat flour. Also just a tip to make bread rise faster, push it out flat on an oiled baking sheet and put it in the oven at about 100 degrees, the dough will rise for the first proof in half the time!

text:
I gave 3 out of 5 because I ended up using reviewers recommendations for a mostly 100% whole wheat loaf.  I used 6 cups of whole wheat flour and 1  cup bread flour, and added 3 tablespoons of flax seed meal and 3table spoons of vital gluten.  I also decided to use olive oil instead of butter (I hate the taste of butter). 

The bread looked beautiful but was so dense and had an off flavor - there was a significant bitter aftertaste.  Unsure why since there was so much honey in the recipe.  

Next time I will try the recipe as is and will add an update.  Overall I'm disappointed with the other reviews.

text:
My boyfriend is a meat n potatoes, stuck n a specific "bachelor healthy" diet. Me being a retired Vegetarian, i thought making bread for his (everymorning) breakfast PB n honey sandwich, i tried this recipe and he loved it! 
Ive made it once before and both times ive added some wheat germ and some random seeds i have (sesame, sunflower, and a trio flax/chia/hemp seed blend) this time i used 1/2 cup molasses when called for honey with bread flour then added some stevia to even out when calling for honey when adding whole wheat. I havent finished baking yet so we will see how it tastes!
Also, i seemed to goof the rising last time but i was trying to make it between work and night school so this time i took a FULL Sunday afternoon to allow it to rise as needed. today its a nice Arkansas hot n humid summer day so its rising alot faster ;) so make sure you give youself plenty of time, make it in-between cleaning house (aka folding clothes while catching up on netflix) Pip

text:
I never write reviews, but this recipe deserves it! I reduced the recipe to 1/3, so I could have just 1 loaf. I first let the yeast hang out in the sugar water (I used sugar because I had no honey) for 10m, then added flour for 30m, per the directions. I used my KitchenAid to knead on 1 for 10m. My first rise was 40m, and my second rise in the loaf pan was only 30m. The size/ proofing was perfect. Just the right density and taste, with a perfect crust. I've never seen my own cooking look like something store-bought!

I used only whole wheat flour, and it came out great! I didnât need much more than the initial 5 cups.  After the first rising that you punch down, it helped to gently roll out the dough into three rectangles with a rolling pin, roll the dough into loaf shapes, and seal the edges before the final rise in the loaf pans.   The loaves came out beautifully, and they taste terrific! Thank you so much for this recipe!

This will definitely be my go-to recipe for wheat bread.

text:
Followed recipe other than using 100% freshly milled whole wheat. Crust is perfect, great flavor. This was excellent for having no white flour in it! Fantastic both for sandwiches and making stellar toast. We like it significantly better than our old favorite- Great Harvest honey wheat bread. Easy recipe for this novice bread baker. Bosch mixer had no issues with the large heavy dough. Cannot recommend this enough, and try milling your own flour. It makes a huge difference!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I only own two loaf pans so I kept everything (except salt) the same and added two cups of organic white flour to the yeast mixture and added enough whole wheat flour to make a beautiful wheat dough.  Everybody in my family loves this.  I've got two more loaves going today and I'm going to add about 1/2 cup of sunflower seeds to the dough while kneading in the whole wheat flour.  This is the easiest bread recipe I've ever made.  Also, I didn't knead it very long (only a minute or two) because I whisked the white flour & yeast mixture for a couple of minutes before adding the rest of the ingredients, which brings out the gluten.  Kneaded dough is ready for first rising when you push down on the ball of dough and it kind of "bounces" back.

text:
I adapted this to make one loaf (why would I want to make fresh bread and then freeze it??). I increased the whole wheat flour to 3/4 of the total. I added an egg and used milk instead of water. I also added 1 T. vital wheat gluten. I let it rise over the evening and overnight to make about a 24-hour total prep time (the kitchen is cool this time of year); the result was wonderful. The long rise (plus egg, milk, and honey!) may help develop the delicious flavor. I'll definitely make this again, and work toward reducing the white flour still more.

text:
I made a half recipe and made some of the add-in changes suggested (flax seed and sunflower seeds) . I also started with whole wheat and added in white. So it was mostly whole wheat. I used my stand KA mixer but had to hold onto it to keep the bowl in place while the dough hook was doing its thing (10 minutes as level 2). I would like to know if anyone has figured out to what internal  temperature of the bread should be to know when it is correctly baked. I usually use temperature as a test for doneness for bread...190-205 depending on the recipe (using an instant read thermometer)...more reliable then the "knocking method" for me. This is the lightest whole wheat bread I have ever made. thanks!

userID:
15966602
Display Name:
Melissa
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

favoritesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3379824.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The search is over... I started baking all of our bread a little over a year ago and have tried so many wheat recipes.  Finally, I have found one that is soft and tasty like the one my kids used to love from a local bakery.  I halved the recipe and added 1.5 tsp. of vital wheat gluten (as instructed by MommyFromSeattle's review) but otherwise, followed the recipe.  I only use SAF Instant yeast (try it!), and measured .25 oz. by weight.  First rise was done in a little under an hour so I deflated it and shaped it for my 10x5 loaf pan, which I greased with PAM spray.  2nd rise was a little quicker and it domed beautifully.  Oven spring was also great and we ended up with a large, soft, beautiful wheat loaf.   I buttered it when it was done for a soft crust and it was hard to wait for it to cool so we could try a slice.  It is now the next day and it's still soft, tasty and made wonderful toast this morning.
  
I will say that, although I measure by weight, I was surprised that after adding the initial measurement of wheat flour the dough came together without adding any of the recommended additional wheat flour.  I know that dough hydration is dependent on so many factors, but if this continues to be the case in my kitchen, then I will decrease the amount of white flour so I can add more wheat!  All and all, we love how it turned out but my oldest child requested that I give it a little more wheat flavor next time.  YAY!

text:
Great bread recipe! I tried so many and failed and this one is so easy and so yummy. I do not have a bread machine so I ended up splitting the dough into two half to make two larger loaves. I also add about a cup of ground flaxseed to the mix instead of some of the whole wheat flour. It gives it a nice texture and taste, IMO. I have found that I need to sometimes bake it a little longer, until the tops are golden, to make sure the inside is not too doughy.

country:
None
text:
Recipe is fantastic - easy to make and results in nice, soft, tasty bread with a hint of honey, with a good blend of regular and whole-wheat flour that makes it not too whole-wheaty, if that makes sense. The loaves bake up extremely well in 9"x4" pullman loaf pans, perfect for sandwiches for kids' lunches. - just 1) make sure to butter the pan, including the lid, 2) put on the lid and bake just as the dough has nearly risen to the lip, and 3) take the lid off 10 minutes before baking is finished. I used King Arthur all-purpose flour rather than bread flour. This recipe's a keeper.

text:
Awesome recipe.  Anyway, made this bread with slight deviations for approximately 26 servings.  Raise times are important, so I cultured the Yeast in small cup of warm water before mixing it in.  Also, placing on top of stove while preheating oven helps raising by keeping wet dish towel warm.  I also added 1 tbsp of flaux seed.  Bread should have 3 basic ingredients: flour, water, and salt (yeast is not true ingredient).  
Next time in grocery store, count how many ingredients their bread has.  I bet you find more and plenty preservatives.

text:
i have found many recipes for wholewheat bread online over the years and the results have ranged from tasteless to brick-like. This always comes out really well and swapping types of flours and sweetening agents is easy to do as it always seems to come out perfectly. Rye (1-2 cups) and spelt (1 cup) and 100% wholewheat all work well. The main thing I love about this bread is that my kids love it. Lovely texture and great taste. I find this quantity makes two great sized loafs rather than the 3 smaller ones as the recipes says.

userID:
17850891
Display Name:
Jenny
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
104
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this wonderful bread with 100% whole wheat flour and it turned out perfectly!  It was my first time to EVER make bread. In addition to following the instructions, I used some tips from some of the other viewers and watched a quick youtube video on basic bread making tips (I didn't even know how to "punch down" the dough so I had to get a little help).  I used the microwave trick for proofing.  The first stage took about 30-45 minutes to double.  After punching down and splitting into three loaves I rolled the dough out into a rectangle with a rolling pin and then gently rolled the dough up and tucked under the ends to make it fit in the loaf pan.  The second proof in the loaf pan took about 45 minutes-1 hr. Baked exactly as directed and cooled immediately on wire rack but did not top with butter.  Rolling the dough out after punching really helped get rid of larger air bubbles. My finished product had no tunneling and very small uniform air pockets. It tastes AMAZING! My husband, who HATES wheat bread, LOVES it! I think most people have reported a 12-slice loaf but I will get 16 out of mine with a thinner slice. I used 7.5 C total of King Arthur's whole wheat flour, best choice active dry yeast (by  the way .25 oz = 1 packet yeast= 2 1/4 tsp roughly), butter and honey in amounts listed on recipe.  No matter how you slice it (pun intended), one loaf (1/3 recipe) has approximately 1328 kcals, 16.5 g total fat, 7.3 g saturated fat, 852 mg sodium, 242 g carbohydrates, 30 g f
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-04-03T18:15:23.46
helpfulCount:
0

text:
This recipe is my go-to sandwich bread. I made it exactly as the recipe calls for and it turned out great. However, I don't care for the honey flavor and smell in all my sandwhiches, etc. (it's great in toast!) So I started using half molasses and half brown sugar, and you can't taste the molasses. I use maybe one cup more whole wheat than the recipe calls for also. To help the dough rise, I put it in the oven with the light on and a pan of hot water underneath, and so far I have had no issues. I also knead it briefly after the first rise, before shaping into loaves. It helps to get the air bubbles out.

I make about the same loaf. It is great. I add about 1/4 cup dry milk powder and switch the amounts of bread flour tow whole wheat flower. Finally, I add about 1/4 mixed seeds: millet, sunflower, pumpkin, caraway and fennel-or whatever combination I have on hand.  This is a good recipe. Make it about 1x per week using the no-knead recipe method. makes two loaves for us to use over the course of the week.  The second has a bit more of a sour dough tang and is really good for toasted cheese sandwiches.

text:
Perfect! So, I have made a few different bread recipes now and this one is by far the best!!! I followed the recipe using about 3 cups of wheat flour to the 5 cups of white flour (all my flour was bread flour). I made TWO large loaves of bread in well greased glass pans, at 350 degrees for 35 minutes. The tops will be a dark golden brown when ready, and tapping on them should sound hollow. You can tap on the tops and on the bottoms once they are out of the dishes. Brush the tops with butter once baking is done and let sit in the dish for 10 minutes. Take out of dish place on bread rack and let cool. Remember you need 2/3 cup of honey in total. It uses 2/3 cup twice in the recipe. I used farmers market raw honey. Yum! (I posted pictures of the loaves done and inside the largest loaf exposing the center under the photos for this recipe) Good luck! It's delicious! I will be making this all the time!

city:

country:
None
text:
I made a few mistakes but think I've got it now.. based on this recipe. 
I used 1 Tbsp yeast to 1 Tbsp sugar to 1 cup warm water. Mixed and let stand 10 minutes until bubbly & cloudy. Mixed in 1 tsp salt & 2.5 cups spelt ww flour in bowl then kneaded on counter surface 5-7 minutes. Put dough ball in greased bowl covered with cloth towel in slightly warm oven (turned on warmer for 2 minutes beforehand) to double in size, about 1 hour. Punched down, folded into log and set in greased baking pan to rise 1" above pan, about 3 hours. Bake at 350 for 25 minutes! Spread melted butter on top as it cools.

text:
Fairly simple to make.  However I am a little confused but just went with my instincts on a few parts....  Could just be the way I interpretted some bits at the time.
Going to attempt to make this again tomorrow, so let's see how it goes then.

FYI, I used a 13x5 pan and a 9x5 pan.  I would recommend still splitting th dough pretty close to in half if you're going to do the same.  I put more dough into the 13x5 and it did not cook all the way through I found out after the second day.  Essentially there was still enough heat retained in the middle of the loaf to keep the yeast activated and it created this HUGE hole right through the middle. lined with raw dough.  Was too late obviously to try and recook at this point, I believe.

text:
I made it per the recipe except that I used my stand mixer with the dough hook rather than working the dough by hand.  It is indeed superb and I expect to make it many more times. The crumb is beautiful, it is moist, and not sweet as I feared.  Next time I will try a bit less white flour and a bit more whole wheat.  Stay tuned...

On 3/23/16 as I edit this review, I've made this recipe three times.  Because I only have two bread tins, I make the last third into cinnamon buns like my Grandma used to.  They are super yummy and freeze well.  

On a well floured surface, pat out the dough into a rectangle.  Don't worry if you can't get the dough to stay out as far as you'd like--I only got mine to perhaps 12" x 7".  Working with the long side toward you, generously butter (no margarine!) between the short edges leaving only about an inch on the top long edge unbuttered.  Generously sprinkle cinnamon on this same portion so you can't see the dough underneath well.  

Roll starting with the long edge near you, pulling a little as you go.  Seal the long edges when finished.  Place the sealed edge down.  If the ends are thicker than the center, pull them a bit, too.  Prepare a medium sized Pyrex rectangular dish by buttering it and pouring about 1/4" of real maple syrup in the bottom. Or, alternatively, use a combo of maple syrup and brown sugar, or even just brown sugar (and perhaps a little more butter).  

Take about a 14" length of sewing thread, slide it under the roll and back

text:
This is a very easy recipe. I reduced the called for ingredients by 2/3  to make one loaf and it came out great. 
A few changes I made: I used a whole packet of yeast, used all whole wheat flour for a healthier bread, used only 1/8 - 1/4c of raw melted honey and it was plenty sweet enough for me, skipped the butter on top of the loaf before baking (the top crust wasn't too hard), and since was making one loaf, I let it rise the second time right in the greased bread pan before baking. 
I only wished I had tried this sooner! I will not be buying expensive, store bought bread again if I can help it.

text:
Makes an absolutely perfect loaf of bread.  I've been looking for a good whole wheat bread, and haven't had a lot of success.  So I played with this recipe a bit - based on suggestions - and added 1 T gluten per cup of whole wheat flour, and replaced 1 cup of bread flour with rye (that's what I had on hand.) The bread was great out of the oven, but the next day it sliced perfectly and made a great sandwich. Will  be playing with this recipe for a while - adding different flours, seeds, etc.  Thanks - this is wonderful.

text:
LOOOOVE THIS BREAD!!! Now, I've made this as-is, and it's fan-fricken'-tastic that way, but, if you want a more healthy bread: you can use ONLY WW flour, and cut the honey in half (I've even used only 1 1/2 tablespoons--added the first time it is called for--for one loaf and it's still wonderful). I do recommend keeping some honey in there, though (the baker who posted this knows what she's doing!). Also, for anyone who is watching their sodium intake, cutting the salt in half won't ruin it. One last thing: if you are only making one loaf and aren't very good at math like me, just use a whole packet (or 2 1/4 tsp) of yeast--the result is the same. Anyway...this bread is just the best with or without alterations. Thank you so, so much, Nita!!

city:
