region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really good simple semi-whole wheat or fully whole wheat bread, so far fool-proof for me, makes three nice loaves of perfect sandwich size.  30 minute bake time. ----------- Had no honey so I made it with sugar instead, 1:1. Did it all by hand, wasn't that hard to do the kneading which I mostly did in the bowl to keep things cleaner.  It didn't take too long to get it evenly textured and "full" of flour.  ----------- The butter brushed on top makes it a lot like a commercial whole wheat or whole grain bread. ----------- Made it for the fourth time.  Substituted in some Amaranth flour and some whole grains (about 1/2 cup each).   Didn't time the rising, but it's very forgiving.  Ran out to the store, took too long, and came back to a HUGE second rise climbing out of the bowl... no problem.  The loaves still rose nicely in the pans, for nice brown, round topped loaves.  -----------  I don't understand why the ones in the video are so flat and pale.  I wish there was some formatting available for these messages.

text:
This was a big hit in my family. The texture was tender but strong enough to hold up to sandwiches and toast. The flavor was just sweet enough and lacked the bitter aftertaste you sometimes get when there's too much whole wheat flour. I will definitely make this again. Be aware that the recipe is just a recipe and not lessons in how to bake bread. You have to already know how to knead, judge how much flour to add in, and so forth.

text:
This bread is awesome!!! It was my first stab at bread-making, so my first attempt was less than perfect. Taste was great, but it came out very dense and was just not quite right all around. I figured it was my fault,  and it was. Did some reading on Epicurious about bread basics, and that helped A LOT. I had also tried to halve the recipe, and that screwed with the measurements.  So, second attempt! With a little more basic knowledge, and with the correct measurements, I was prepared and in control! The dough was perfectly workable, and behaved exactly as it should. I used a thermometer to achieve 190 degree centers in my three loaves, and they came out looking beautiful and tasting delicious! I used all wheat bread, but otherwise changed nothing. Thank you for this great recipe!

userID:

Display Name:
FeliD

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok I was completely new to baking bread and this recipe is so good and easy that even I could make it and turned out wonderful! Just a couple of tips ( not changes). This makes a lot of dough and while the first rise it almost blew over the largest bowl I had so I started separating the badges. I make 2 good sized sandwich loafs out of that amount of dough so I just cut the recipe in half and make it in 2 bowls. Otherwise the loafs are a little to small for sandwiches! I also make enough for the whole week and freeze the dough. All you gotta do is punch it down after the second rise, wrap it loosely in plastic wrap and then put it in a large zip lock bag and off into the freezer. When needed I take it out at night and let it defrost in the fridge. The next morning I warm up the oven for a minute on lowest setting turn it off but leave the light on, and put the dough into the bread pan, cover it and put it in the nice and cozy warm oven. It will take an hour or two to rise but it will and then you bake it as usually. Just don't take the warm towel off when you take the loaf out of the oven to preheat because it happened to me that the dough completely flattened out because it was pretty chilly in my house! But again, this recipe is amazing and I am glad I found it! Please excuse any mis spelling because I am German so this is my second language. But I still hope that my tips will help!

country:
None
text:
It was alarmingly sweet, and all that sugar is so unnecessary to make a good bread! I cut the sugar(honey) down to ONLY 1/4 cup. I added it in at the first step with the yeast and followed the directions as is. After it proofed, I added in the wheat flour with the salt mixed in, (omitting the second 1/3 of honey completely) and replaced melted butter with olive oil. After it was baked I brushed it with the tiniest amount of butter, maybe 1/4ts per loaf, and was more than enough (this step is only for crust texture, we are not buttering the bread for flavor!) This is my new favorite bread, and I will be making over and over again!

text:
What I love about this bread recipe is that there are so many variations possible. I can make it savory, sweet, plain, anything I want. Sometimes, instead of baking 3 loaves, I'll bake 2 and use the remaining dough to make cinnamon rolls. I kneaded this by hand, which was kind of difficult, but it all worked out. If it's a cloudy day and there's no warm spot, I turn the oven to 350 for 45 seconds then put the dough in to rise.

userID:
15890143
Display Name:
Lina Linn
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2338114.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This bread came out fantastic. I would make this over and over again!  I cut the recipe in half incase I didn like the bread and I ended up using whole wheat flour for the whole recipe.  Since wheat flour is a bit denser I ended up using less flour. Otherwise my measurements were 2.5 cups wheat flour at first mixed with 1/4 oz yeast, 1/6 cup of honey and 1 1/2 warm water.  The mixture will be sticky at first so I let it ride for a good 30 minutes.  I pressed it down and added about 1 1/4 cup wheat flour, 1/6 cup honey, sprinkle of salt, and 1 1/2 tablespoon honey.  I kneeded the dough and let it rise for a good hour.  I kneeded the dough one last time in my bread baker and let it rise for one hour in a warm area and baked it on 350 for approximately 25 mins.  Melted one tablespoon of butter I poured over and sprinkled with rolled oats. Yum!!!!

I tried adding a homemade dough enhancer - wheat gluten, potato flakes, and a very small amount of white vinegar - and it came out PERFECT.  It held together with very little crumb.  This is definitely now my go-to bread recipe.

None
text:
This recipe is WONDERFUL! My family eats one loaf as soon as it emerges from the oven. I make two regular loaves, then roll out the other and sprinkle cinnamon-sugar all over it before rolling it back up. Also, instead of melting butter, I rub the end of a stick of butter over the tops while hot, skipping the brush and the melting step, while not using any more butter than is necessary. Enjoy!

text:
I been on a bread tear all month long and I'm happy to report that this recipe is the winner. By far. Way better than that pesky Amish White Bread listed on the site. The idea of just a few hours of rising time is a absolute joke though. I admit, we keep the house pretty chilly, but, for me, this bread took almost 8 hours to rise all told. I usually just prepare it in the morning, put it covered in the sunny windowsill and then go about my day. I use one, refrigerate one, and freeze one and that usually last me and my boyfriend a month at least. Get some pepper jack and make yourself a grilled cheese sandwich that will blow your mind.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe! I modified a little after I read other reviewers. I used more whole wheat than bread flour (2:1) and cut recipe in half and made one large loaf. As I usually do when I bake any bread, I dissolve sugar (honey) in warm water and mix dry yeast and wait until foaming, and mix all liquid ingredient, then add one cup of flour at a time in Kitchen Aid mixer. Once mixed, I turn up to level 2 for 3 min with dough hook, then take dough out, rest 15 min then knead with hand for 5-8 min. When you bake, I put baking dish with shallow water on the lowest oven rack. It came out perfect!

text:
My kids say this is the best bread they have ever had, and the 3 loaves rarely last longer than 4 days in my house (I have alot of kids though). The first time I made it I had never made bread in my life, and I wanted to use flax meal also.  I subbed 1/2 cup of the whole wheat for flax meal.  I don't think I had enough moisture because my loaves didn't rise well.  Regardless the bread was delicious and got eaten, was just very dense.  The second time I started with 3.5 cups of water and everything turned out perfectly.  I am going to try adding more whole wheat flour and less bread flour over my next several times of making this bread, however want to get bread making down as I have now only made it 2 time in my life!

text:
This is a great whole wheat sandwich bread! It's pretty sweet, so I might cut down on the honey a little bit next time, but the kids won't leave it alone. The first time I made it, I made three loaves, but this time I made two large loaves, instead of three, because it's easier to eyeball breaking things into equal halves than thirds. These are the most beautiful loaves of sandwich bread I have made! They are a perfect color and shape. I baked them for 30 minutes.

country:
None
text:
This was simply an amazing bread, and I have made a lot of breads in twenty years. I did make a change---my honey was solidified so I added an egg to make up for lack of liquid  (I have found the solidified honey as a sweetener makes really good bread). I also halved the recipe and mixed in my bread machine because my machine couldn't handle that much flour. I ended up with two loaves (after mixing in machine and let rise for an hour and half I shaped the loaves and let rise for another hour). My boys loved the slices with butter and I made sandwiches with the extra loaf. Great sandwich bread, I have to say! I am thinking would make really good toast also. Will have to make again to try for breakfast toast (; Great texture, held up well slicing. Definitely going into my bread rotation.

- The smell of the house as it baked - amazing.
- The look of the golden brown bread when it came out of the oven to cool - amazing.

really liked this recipe, but using that much flour, the bread didn't rise correctly and was extremely dense.  using 1 cup less white flour helped the flour to rise properly. also I mixed the yeast into 1-2 cups of 110 degree water first until it was foamy before I added it to my mixer.

text:
PERFECT!  I love love love this recipe.  I have tried several bread recipes, and this trumps them all.  Really easy, really forgiving, and tasty too! I've used sugar instead of honey (when I'm out of honey)and it turns out the same.  I also add 3 Tbl of wheat gluten to get that soft chewy store bought texture so my kids and husband will eat it and prefer it to store bought.  It freezes well, and doesn't dry out the next day like the others have.  Very happy with this recipe, it will be my "go to" homemade bread recipe.

country:
None
text:
I really liked this recipe!  I have been looking for a handmade bread recipe (I like to knead dough!) that would yield a soft but yeasty tasting bread and this is it!  I made three minor adjustments, already recommended by many, adding some vital wheat gluten, about 5 tbsp, olive oil instead of butter and switched up the ratio of white to ww flour, 5 cups of ww and 3 cups of white.  Other than that I followed the directions of the original recipe.  It is very yummy, was an easy to work with dough, it cooperated with two good rises, even though my yeast had to have been not so fresh.

I can see modifying this recipe even further, quite easily, adding flax or chia seeds, etc.  This is a very easy to make, follow and enjoy bread recipe!

text:
You can't just DO this to people, sharing recipes like this. Next thing you know,everyone will be neglecting all of their other responsibilities so they can bake this bread all day. 

I made two regular loaves and then rolled out the third ball of dough, cut it into 10 strips (pizza cutter), rolled each strip up and put them in a round pan. It made an absolutely BEAUTIFUL pan of rolls (and I am very much a bread-making novice).

Tomorrow, I will try this dough recipe with the awesome Clone of a Cinnabon recipe's cinnamon filling and icing ( http://allrecipes.com/recipe/clone-of-a-cinnabon/) and make whole wheat cinnamon rolls.

Thanks so much for sharing this recipe!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/951295.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my 3rd batch of bread I have made in the past week, and I never made bread before that, and I think I like this one the best so far.  When I went to buy the whole wheat flour, I wasn't sure if I needed WW BREAD flour, or just regular WW Flour.  To be on the safe side I bought the WW bread flour.  Once I got home and started to get all the ingredients together I realized that the WW bread flour was a mix of white and whole wheat.  So after adding 5 cups of bread flour, I think my bread is more white than brown.  Either way, it turned out fantastic and I ended up with 3 nice sized loaves.  After reading the reviews I was expecting to only make 2, but there way way too much dough to make just 2.  It turned out really moist with great flavour.  I'm looking for a bread recipe as a replacement for store bought, and so far the ones I have tried have turned out well and taste great, but have not been able to hold up to sandwich quality without falling apart.  I let my dough rise too long so it ended up a little 'holier', so I'm expecting it might not work well for sandwiches.  But I am looking forward to trying this one again, with WW flour and less rising time.

We have a little one here who can't have honey, so I switched out the honey for: 3tbls of brown rice syrup in yeast mixture while it proofs. Then 2.5tbs sugar into the bread mixture. The yeast still becomes wonderfully foamy, and the bread is delicious and sweet! (I make 2 loaves instead of 3. If you use the full recipe, you should sub in more rice syrup and sugar.)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Breadmaker from start to finish & absolutely beautiful & tasty. Hearty, yet light & fluffy with the following additions. 1/3 recipe made a 1-1/2# loaf. Added everything in order (water temp was hot tub warm, maybe 98F. Wasn't precise on measurements but used as a guide. Changes: added SALT before the flour, also added on top everything: 1T (1/3 recipe) vital wheat gluten, 1T ground flax seeds, 1T poppy seeds, 2T chia seeds after adding them to 1/2 C hot water & letting them set for 5 min which makes them turn into a gel. In the early part of the 2nd rise, I topped the unrisen loaf w/ more poppy seeds, some oats & some toasted white sesame seeds.

text:
I've never made bread before, but my bread turned out PERFECT. My family and I loved the flavour. Because I didn't have bread pans, I used old round pots that didn't have the normal thick bottom, so I only cooked them for 25mins. When I placed them in the thicker bottomed pots, it took longer to cook, but the top of the bread turned dark brown, so I switched to the thin bottom ones. Thank you Nita for this EASY and delicious recipe.

ok, so this was my first time making bread, and it tasted ok, but there were a few errors on my part that made this bread less than amazing.... i found myself out of honey and used sugar instead, not taking into account that honey would probably make it less dry, as it is a liquidy ingredient. i also bought the wrong size pans and so i only had 2 really big loaves that ended up being almost raw in the middle. i plan on trying this again in the near future because, like i said, the errors were entirely my fault and the bread that i tried tasted pretty good :)

This bread is amazing. As always I tweaked the recipe to fit the ingredients on hand (a mixture of 3 types of flour) and added more honey.  I've made loads of bread but this was the best recipe yet.  Adding the melted butter before the kneading and second rise, as well as brushing the loaves with butter out of the oven were perfect additions. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this bread today and had trouble stop myself from eating it all up. I halved the recipe and used two loaf pans of size 8.5x4.5. My loafs are smaller than the regular sandwich bread, but who cares about the size and/or shape when the bread tastes so good! I made it by hand and didn't measure the exact amount of whole wheat flour I added. I was a little nervous about reaching the right 'stickiness', but I do believe the other review was right that this is a very forgiving recipe. Definitely a keeper and will be one of the recipes I keep using. BTW I just started to do homemade bread, by hand, not long ago and will consider myself novice-intermediate baker. So if I can do it, you can too!

text:
I make this bread using my bread machine. Let me start by saying I converted the recipe to make only one loaf. I follow step 1 using my bread machine pan. After adding the ingredients listed in step 2 I turn on the machine using the dough cycle. After the dough has doubled I take it out of the machine and transfer it to a greased 9x5 baking pan. From then on I follow the recipe exactly as listed. This is my son's favorite bread. Thank you for a recipe that I can feel good about making and serving my family.

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2009-09-03T21:24:40.25
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
3973723
Display Name:
tut078620
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
10
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This came out wonderfully.  I reduced the honey and about halved the second calling for honey.  I also added 1/4 cup of ground flax seed and 3 tablespoons of vital wheat gluten.  I did use King Arthur bread flour (I originally was going to use plain all purpose flour, but decided not to).  I ended up added maybe 1.5 - 2 additional cups of whole wheat flour.  I think next time I will make three loaves, or remove some from the dough ball and do little buns or something.  I used two loaf pans and they got so huge, it looked like giant mushroom slices.  The rise got so big that once it was cooked and cooled down, the sides dragged down a little--it was probably four to five inches higher than the loaf pan.  I took the advice and heated up my oven, let it cool down a little and left the light on and then put the bowl in for the first rise covered with a damp paper towel.  About an hour later, I punched it down and put it in the loaf pans and since the oven was still warm, I didn't have to reheat it and put the loaves in there to rise again for about another hour.  I used olive oil to brush the tops and it is so so good with a subtle chewy texture and moist.  You don't even need to butter them up to make them taste good! Just eat them plain and you will be quite satisfied.  This is my fourth time making bread, the first three times came from a different recipe - 1 came out dense, 2nd I left too long to rise and it had a bad taste from the yeast, and third it was okay, but did not t
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2009-08-29T16:10:19.803

text:
I decided to make this recipe based on the one negative, one-star review I saw of it. The writer said it was too dense and chewy, which is exactly what I want in a homemade bread. Loved how this recipe turned out. I used different quantities of white vs whole wheat flour and added some ground flax seed because...well, I wanted to. I also had several long, unscheduled interruptions to the process thanks to my small children, but it proofed perfectly anyway, and the final product is delicious. It does have a somewhat dense, chewy texture, but not overly so. It's perfect for sandwiches and toast. This will definitely be my go-to recipe for bread from now on. If you want to make changes to the types of flour/dry indgr, go for it; just follow the directions for what the dough should be like (slightly sticky) and the end product should be fine.

text:
This was a very clear, straightforward recipe.  I enjoyed making the bread - even kneading it by hand.  I was short on ingredients (no bread flour and only 2 c wheat flour), but I really needed some bread, so I halved the recipe and made one single 9x5 loaf.  I substituted white sugar for the first round of honey.  It was perfectly baked in 25 minutes.  Husband and I enjoyed the bread with soup tonight.  It was fabulous.  I will definitely make this recipe again--with bread flour next time.

text:
Admittedly, I did not follow the directions for this bread because I am already set in my breadmaking ways.  I proofed the yeast and honey and then added the ingredients with the flour being last. Everything worked out well :D. I added about 1/2 cup of a mixture of sesame seeds, golden flax seeds, and wheat germ before the flour also. I also scaled this recipe down for 2 loaves. I will definitely make this recipe again. The bread stayed soft in a bag for several days. I just used it for french toast  (Fluffy French Toast) and it turned out rather well :).

text:
This bread is SOOOOO good!  My husband compared it to Outback's bread they bring you before the meal!  (and he's really picky!)  Buttering the top gave it enough 'butter flavor' that we didn't even need to butter the individual pieces.

It does make a lot of dough!  I made 2 loaves of bread and cinnamon rolls out of what would have been the third loaf.  They were good, but almost too sweet.  (the dough itself is pretty sweet, then adding the 'smear' and then the icing-sweet tooth addicts' dream!)

I should mention that before this, I've only tried making bread two times- and neither time did it turn out.  So the fact that this turned out AND it tasted good...  It's gotta be a good recipe!  :)

text:
this recipe is by far the best wheat bread recipe i've made (~4-5 different recipes many times).  it is soft, great texture, and just the right density.  works great for grilled cheese, french toast, and sandwich bread, not to mention fresh and hot with butter or EVOO on top.  i made it in my bread maker, but would do the first few steps in a bowl next time and start at the kneading process for the breadmaker.  also needed to cook a bit longer than the 27 min i gave it.  i'll probably try ~32-33 min next time for the bake.

This was a very good bread! I cut it down to only one loaf since I was low on ingredients, but I followed the recipe as written. It seemed a little low on liquids - I got in all the bread flour and about 2/3 of the wheat flour, and that soaked up all the moisture. My dough wasn't even tacky. The loaf came out rather short and dense, but it was quite tasty! I'll have to play with it and see if I can get it a little lighter, but it's well worth multiple tries.

text:
I made this bread at 1/2 the scale, and I got about 14 dinner rolls and one small loaf.  I used all wheat flour, but the bread was very soft and had a great texture, especially when spread with a little butter.  I didn't have any honey, so I used brown sugar. Fairly easy for not having a bread machine.

text:
Absolutely delicious!  I used a 50/50 white to wheat flour and next time I'll use even more of the wheat.  The dough was incredibly easy to work with, and the bread ended up so soft and delicious.  I accidentally added WAY less salt in my haste (1 tsp), and it was still wonderful.  My kids enjoyed it with soup last night, and this morning ate it with peanut butter, and with butter and honey.
